folder: St. Lukes Place & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: St. Lukes Place - Hudson Street
text:
2, 3 to 13 St. Luke's Place, north side, adioining and east of Hudson Street, seen from Hudson Park on the south side. St. Luke's Place is the eastern extension of Leroy Street cut through the Trinity Church Cemetery in the 1840's. That part of the Trinity Church Farmi on the east side of Hudson Street, from Clarkson to Morton Streets, Was early set aside for a cemetery. After Leroy Street was cut through, the southern half continued to serve as a cemetery until the 1890's, when the bodies were moved up to the cemetery on upper Broadway, and the old cemetery converted into a park, called St. John's Park (not to be confused with St. John's Park on lower Varick Street), later Hudson Park, and opened to the
public in 1898.
The northern half was promptly built up, and a little later named St. Luke's Place, with its own set of house numbers, which replaced the odd numbers 99-ol Leroy Street. Nos. 1-2 age the side of 420 Hudson Street, the corner building. No. 4ds, at the time of this picture, the residence of Mayor James J. Walker.
March 9, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

2-St. Luke's Place, north side, in foreground, entrance to no l6

P. L. Sperr  September 24, 1938
3-St. Luke's Place, north sidr, from Hudson Street, looking
westward.
P. L. Sperr  eptember 24, 1938

folder: Hudson Street & Leroy Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Hudson Street,East side,south from and including Clarkson Street. At this point we are looking back on the business section of Hudson Street;from this point Horth it is still largely a residential,(if somewhat slummy), district,as it was south of here prior to the building operations of
the 1920's.
June I5,I930.
(2) Hudson Street,East Side,southward from Leroy Street clearing
between Clarkson and Houston Streets.
October 2nd,I938
Photographs by,
P.L.Sperr,
No Reproductions.

folder: Leroy Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
109, 107, 105-103 Leroy Street, west of, adjoining and at N.W. corner of Hudson Street. No. 105-103 is the side of 423 Street, the corner building. No. 107 is the little old house
the dormer windows.
June 3, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & Leroy Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Hudson Street, at the N.E. corner of Leroy Street. Also shown (aoross clearance), is Leroy Street, at the S.E. corner of Greervich Street.
March 28, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Hudson Street & Leroy Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
420-436 Hudson Street, east side, between Leroy (right) and Morton (left) Streets, as seen through clearance on the west side (former site of the
Mirror Candy Company Building).
March 28, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: St. Lukes Place & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: St. Lukes Place - Hudson Street
text:
No. 6 St. Luke's place, (Leroy Street), north side, east of Hudson Street. This, an autographed copy, was the residence of Mayor James J. Walker.

About 1929.

C.W.W. Sutcliff.
Gift of Mary A. Leonard.

Neg. No. 97A

folder: St. Lukes Place & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: St. Lukes Place - Hudson Street
text:
No. 6 St. Luke's Place (Leroy Street), north side, east of Hudson Street, showing the former residence of Mayor James J. Walker.

1939

Gift of Museum Photographers Association
Beecher Ogden, photo
